articles.title: About this site
articles.description: What is this website and why does it exist?
articles.contents:
This is the personal website for Kyle Conniff. Information about his research and teaching histories can be found under the similarly labeled pages. See below for what can be found under each of the pages.

articles.title: Curriculum Vitae
articles.contents: This is where a CV should be posted for Kyle Conniff. However, the CV used for grad school applications is currently missing in action (read: did not look very hard), and does not include very much detail anyways. Plus, practicing creating new pages is more fun than uploading some boring sheet anyways. This will be updated later.

articles.title: Home
articles.contents:
I am a Ph.D. student of statistics at the University of California Irvine (UCI). I am working under the direction of Dan Gillen, Ph.D in censored suvival data for Native American health care. I received a Bachelor’s of Arts from St. Norbert College (SNC) in mathematics in 2016. I strive to teach and aid non-statistical faculty in their teaching of statistical thinking.


Curriculum Vitae


Education:





B.A., in Mathematics, St. Norbert College, De Pere, WI, USA (2016)


Honors and Awards:


National Science Foundation Graduate Research Fellowship Program (2017)


Eugene Cota-Robles Fellowship Recipient (2016)


Diversity Fellowship Recipient (2016)


McNair Scholar (2013)


Certificates:


Course Design Certificate Program (2020)

articles.title: Who is Kyle Conniff?
articles.description: If you want to know more about Kyle the human, read on!
articles.contents:
Beyond teaching and academics, Kyle has quite a few hobbies that fall into two big categories: sports and geeks.


Sports


 He currently plays professional Ultimate for the Los Angeles Aviators. As an undergraduate, he studied abroad in Perth, Australia where he learned how to play ultimate. Since he was abroad, Kyle spent way too much getting better at ultimate. After returning to the states, he immediately tried out for a pro team. It took 3 tries, but he first made the Aviators in 2019 and has played with them since. To the left is a photo of Kyle playing in his first Game of the Week in front of an international audience (PC: Meg Hofner). This particular throw ended up making the top plays of the week (well, technically, the catch made the top plays of the week). The video is below.




 Kyle has also been an active juggler since 2009. His best friend at the time was one of the world’s best jugglers and they spent many hours every week working on the ultimate craft for introverts. The picture to the right (PC: Casey Rentmeester) is a classic 5 club cascade (the normal juggling pattern for an odd number of objects). Before moving to California, Kyle attended a few juggling conventions annually and even prepared to participate in a technical juggling competition. Although he didn’t compete, Kyle trained for 3 hours a day to prepare for competition. At the time, his personal records are 9 balls, 7 rings, and 6 clubs. Nowadays, Kyle juggles for about an hour a week split across 3-4 days. If he juggles with other people, he much prefers to work on passing patterns (2 or more people juggling together by throwing objects back and forth) with 6, 7, and 8 clubs, or to play combat with 3 clubs.


Geeks


When Kyle is recovering from his more active endeavors, he watches a lot of anime. His favorites are old-school: Yu Yu Hakusho and Rurouni Kenshin. However, he has watched a lot of good anime and definitely recommends:

Soul Eater


Toradora


Love, Chuunibyou & Other Delusions


My Hero Academia


Seven Deadly Sins.


Sticking with the theme of escapism, Kyle loves to read science fiction, fantasy, and dystopian future novels in the young adult genre. He especially loves 3-10 book series where he can feel as though he has a connection with the main characters. Some of his favorites include:

The Name of the Wind (by Patrick Rothfuss)


The Hunger Games (by Suzanne Collins)


The Novice (by Taran Matharu)


Graceling (by Kristin Cashore)


An Ember in the Ashes (by Sabaa Tahir)


Kyle’s only vices come from having a bit of a card collection problem (Yu-Gi-Oh!, Yu Yu Hakusho, Original Pokemon sets, and original Digimon sets…so far), and playing a relatively small and selective set of video games. Well, he might also be very addicted to sugar.


More information to come when Kyle is finally able to adopt the objectively cutest animal ever (the exact animal is TBD, but it will undoubtedly be the best and cutest).

articles.title: Research
articles.contents:
My research is currently focused on developing statistical methods for censored survival data. My research focus iS driven by an application to Native American health care systems and disparities. My first dissertation problem is to extend time-dependent AUROC curves to the multivariate case, which is necessary for my second dissertation project: calibrating risk sets for electronic health records data. On the side, I am (lightly) working on sports analytics for ranking Ultimate teams and identifying the most useful metrics for predicting the winner of a game.


Collaborations


Center for American Indian and Alaskan Native Health (Link)


The center is currently working on understanding dementia in AIAN populations via two main pathways and two main outcomes. On the pre-dementia end, the goal is to understand what sociodemographic factors are associated with onset of dementia and what modifiable risk factors influence the onset of dementia, with a special emphasis on the relationship between diabetes and dementia. After developing dementia, the goal is to understand if (and how) health service utilization changes, what is most effective, and the resulting costs.


Research Interests


My research interests are primarily driven by the areas of application and/or in applied directions. Listed below are my main statistical areas of interest with reasons/applications sub-listed below the topics:

Survival Analysis


Health disparities


Native American health


Health care costs


Electronic health records


Sports Stats


Rankings


Outcome Prediciton


Strategy Development


Strategy Analysis


Player Development


Pedagogy


Remote Teaching


Flipped Classrooms


Using internet resources to improve learning


Developing introductory material for non-stats students taking stats courses


Developing applications for aiding and teaching students of statistics


Time series


Concussions


Head Trauma


Stress


Neuroimaging


Sleep

articles.title: Teaching
articles.contents:
Uh oh, this site is under construction. Please check back after Kyle has done some teaching.


Kyle has started developing two resources for teaching introductory statistics. The original ideas and (much appreciated) guidance come from Dr. Mine Dogucu. The goal is to turn these projects into useful tools for teaching students the basics of statistics.

R Package


R Shiny


The two projects currently work together to help students calculate z-scores, t-scores, quantiles, and p-values from the information that will be given in a typical introductory question. There is also an option to visualize the distribution and area to which the probability corresponds. The projects are only in the very formative stages, with many more ideas for adding to them. Some of the goals include:

Guide for choosing the right test


Guide for using the right formula


Step-by-step solutions for the z- and t-score questions


Rejection regions on visualization plot


Multiple plots for thinking about conversions from “original units” to “standard units”


Expanding to two-sample cases


Expanding to other introductory topics


Many more ideas to be sorted through
